columns.text: This task asks what the current price of the Weismann Co. bond is if the payment of the bond is semiannual and the bond was issued a year ago.

Yield to maturity is what an investor will earn if he holds the bond until the maturity date when the issuer pays back all the promised interest payments and the amount of the debt written in the contract (principal). We can say that this is a nominal interest rate at the annual level. 

Coupon rates are determined by the entity that issues a bond. The coupon value will be the same for every future payment. So it is a fixed amount.

Let's calculate the value of the annual coupon.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{annual coupon}&=\text{coupon rate}\times\text{face value}\\[15pt]
&=4.9\%\times\$1,000\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$49}
\end{aligned}$$

That is the value of the annual coupon. We need to calculate the semiannual coupon rate.

To solve the exercise, we should use the formula for calculating the bond's price.

$$\text{price of the bond}=\text{C}\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^\text{-n}}{\text{YTM}}+\dfrac{\text{F}}{\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^\text{n}}$$

$C$ - coupon

$YTM$ - bond yield

$F$ - par value

$n$ - period

If we insert the date in the previous formula, we will get the following result.

$$\text{price of the bond}=\$49\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+4.5\%\right)^{-15}}{4.5\%}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+4.5\%\right)^{15}}$$

We should divide the coupon rate by two because the bondholder will get semiannual payments. We need to divide YTM by two because the exercise is given an annual rate. The period we have to multiply by two because the bondholder will get the payment 30 times if he holds the bond until maturity. 

*Because the bond was issued a year ago, two periods have passed. That is the reason why we will have 28 periods left.*

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{price of the bond}&=\$24.5\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+2.25\%\right)^{-28}}{2.25\%}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+2.25\%\right)^{28}}\\[15pt]
&=\$24.5\times\dfrac{1-0.5363}{0.025}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{1.8645}\\[15pt]
&=\$24.5\times20.607+\$536,329\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$1,0410.216}
\end{aligned}$$

**The price of the Weismann Co. bond is \$1,0410.216.**
